awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project will be a blockchain-based timebank that results in a shared empowerment system that leverages students’ strengths and addresses the corresponding potential obstacles. If successful, this empowerment system may promote tangible employment skills, improve trust and relationships, and develop social capital within participants. The proposed timebanking system may help channel the collaborative spirit at universities and foster communities that are actively engaged. In addition, it also may offer students an avenue to practice leadership skills while experimenting in a convenient low-risk setting. The proposed technology may provide students with an opportunity to gradually build up confidence for transitioning from a market incubator environment into a real market. This tech-based system could also serve a broader set of participants such as homemakers and elderly communities. 

This I-Corps project will be a borderless, digital timebanking system built upon blockchain, in which the participants interchange skills through their time rather than money. Using the proposed technology, participants leverage their unique skills to provide services to other members of their social network and are compensated with a time-credit for future services provided by other members of the network rather than with money. With the proposed blockchain technology, the goal is to create a trustworthy system in which users’ credentials are proved via a traceable and decentralized ledger while the meaningful contributions of the participants may be credited for the value they offer. The technology may improve the trust and transparency between users and their skill statements, diminishes the chance of fake reviews and late transactions, and facilitates participation growth by incentivizing individuals to contribute services to the social network. A novel cryptographic protocol called zero-knowledge proof (ZKP) will be applied in this skill-exchange network. With ZKP, ethical behavior is enforced while privacy, secure anonymity, and the flexibility of sharing identities will be maintained. This protocol allows users’ information to be validated without the need to expose their data. It also may help users to interact with digital services that they can trust.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
We started with undergrad students as our first customer segment since we believed they have enough time and passion for learning and helping. However, after about 20 interviews we found that most of their needs are academic ones which are well-provided by the university. We got the same feedback from grad students. They were mainly satisfied with the help they got from their advisor or lab mates? support. Students sounded like a really good customer segment at first. However, they turned out to have minor issues and challenges with the university support system, so we had to pivot and change our customer segment.

Trying to redirect our customer segment we came up with the retired adults. We believed this group of people lack a community with which they can exchange their experiences. From our perspective, they could get excited about a platform which can provide them with the opportunity to give and receive help, service, and advice from other retirees. After about 10 interviews, we noticed that these people are either too far away from the technology or too uninterested about helping. They wanted to spend more time with their family rather than other people.

Another customer segment that we went through were nonprofit organizations for youths as an effective part of the ecosystem for young people. We interviewed several executive directors to see if they need to improve their connections with each other and find volunteers more efficiently. However, once again we could not validate our problem statement by having NPOs as the customer segment since they couldn?t afford such platforms, so we needed to move on to the next potential customer.

Following our journey, we started enquiring homemakers/ Housewives. We assumed that they might be willing to have useful connections with other homemakers. Talking to homemakers and housewives we got some positive feedbacks. They show some passion to find out about other homemakers? experiences, but the positive feedbacks were not enough for us consider them as a serious customer segment. In fact, they have already been in many other platforms and groups which helped them get connected.

We got a suggestion from teaching team about exploring time banking among employees in the corporates.
After couple of interviews, we came up with three subsegments. First segment is high-tech companies such as Facebook, Microsoft, or Google that they already have their own internal platforms for connectivity and finding other colleagues with special expertise. Second one was the corporate using existing platforms or managerial support and they are satisfied with that. The third one is corporates in which employees do not use existing platforms for finding their needs. After a while we found that only the employers and employees from the third group might be interested to our platform. However, the problem was that even if the platform could add a value to the administrative system from the management perspective, employees might not be interested in using them.

After more than 100 interviews with representatives of different segments we came up with some basic knowledge for future works:

-        Customer segments are better be from the people who have already worked with other social media platforms.

-        Segments are needed to be defined thoroughly. We must be more specific in choosing the next customer segments. We also need to come up with more subsegments while doing the interviews.

-        Questions play an important role in getting a decent result. We need to avoid questions that give interviewees the self-confirmation vibes. Therefore, questions are needed to be indirect and explicit.

-        After finding a good customer segment, the other Business Model canvas segments are needed to be addressed when questions are being designed. Meaning that the answers we get from the questions should indicate the strategy we better take regarding each of the segments.

-        In doing the interviews, we need to avoid confirmation bias.
